International flights to and from Bhutan remain severely limited due to travel restrictions on Bhutanese citizens and carriers, as well as border closures. Bhutanese air carriers, such as Druk Air (KB) and Bhutan Airlines (B3), are operating some flights mainly to repatriate Bhutanese citizens. Schedules for available flights are subject to change at short notice. Fully vaccinated international arrivals can quarantine at designated facilities for 14 days, while unvaccinated entrants are subject to a 21-day quarantine. Reports indicate that authorities allow foreign tourists to enter Bhutan, though these entrants are still subject to mandatory quarantine upon arrival.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211208164832/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/550486/bhutan-authorities-continuing-to-enforce-covid-19-restrictions-nationwide-as-of-nov-29-update-36

The country will begin the COVID vaccine booster doses for the priority group across the country from 24th December. The priority group includes all residents above the age of 18 in the high-risk areas, elderly above 65 years across the country, persons with chronic medical conditions, all health workers and all outbound travellers above the age of 18.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211216122329/http:/www.bbs.bt/news/?p=163225

In tandem with the governmentâs commitment to narrow the gap, and to promote people-centered health services with care and compassion, the Ministry of Health (MoH) launched a Priority Signage, Health and Wellbeing Handbook, coinciding with the International Day for Older Persons.    The priority signage will be displayed in all the health facilities across the country, and this will facilitate the older people 65 years and above, and people living with disability to access health services on priority.    The Health and Wellbeing Handbook will be issued to all the older people who visit the health facilities. The handbook will be used to document all medical conditions, treatment, any home bound care needs, and follow up checkups.    The Health Minister Dasho Dechen Wangmo said the health ministry has registered around 20,043 elderly people, and out of which, around 15,000 have health conditions with comorbidities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210316113848/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/03-09-20-the-new-normal-for-caring-for-elderly-children-persons-with-disabilities/    https://web.archive.org/web/20211209114618/https://thebhutanese.bt/moh-launches-priority-signage-for-the-elderly-people-in-all-the-health-facilities-across-the-country/

The country will begin the COVID vaccine booster doses for the priority group across the country from 24th December. The priority group includes elderly above 65 years across the country    https://web.archive.org/web/20211216122329/http:/www.bbs.bt/news/?p=163225

The health ministry will, however, continue to administer COVID-19 vaccines for:    1. Children as and when they turn 1    2 years. 2. All those who enter the country with no or partial vaccination.    3. Administer second dose for those who have received the first dose. Second dose for ages 12 to 17 years will be provided in the second and third week of October. This will take the total vaccine coverage to about 80 percent. An update will be shared soon after.    4. Those who were unable to take the vaccine so far due to unavoidable social or health reasons such as acute illness or being pregnant or breast feeding at the time. We would like to reiterate here that the vaccine is safe for pregnant and lactating women, and many have also come forward until now. Unless specified otherwise by the treating physician, there are no medical conditions that restrict individuals from taking the COVID-19 vaccination. Please note that all eligible individuals who are not vaccinated yet can choose to take the vaccine within October 2021. The government will also arrange vaccines for children below 12 years, as and when the international and national regulatory bodies approve. Announcements will be made accordingly. Should there be major changes in the global COVID-19 vaccine scenario and trend, we will work towards a vaccination campaign for the entire population at a different time. For now, we do not encourage booster doses beyond the second dose, until stronger evidence evolves. We encourage everyone to continue practicing health habits of washing hands, wearing masks and keep away from crowd to avoid potential threats as the pandemic persists with the same risks.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211021230556/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/06-09-21-%f0%9d%90%88%f0%9d%90%a6%f0%9d%90%a9%f0%9d%90%a8%f0%9d%90%ab%f0%9d%90%ad%f0%9d%90%9a%f0%9d%90%a7%f0%9d%90%ad-%f0%9d%90%a7%f0%9d%90%a8%f0%9d%90%ad%f0%9d%90%a2%f0%9d%90%9c%f0%9d%90%9e/

The country will begin the COVID vaccine booster doses for the priority group across the country from 24th December. The priority group includes all residents above the age of 18 in the high-risk areas, elderly above 65 years across the country, persons with chronic medical conditions, all health workers and all outbound travellers above the age of 18. According to the ministry, there are close to 230,000 people in the priority group.    The ministry will provide the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines as booster doses for the priority group. However, Astrazeneca and Covishield will be provided as a choice for those who have received these vaccines as their first and second dose.    Similarly, the health ministry on its Facebook page last month shared the ministry is exploring to vaccinate children aged five to eleven years with the Pfizer paediatric vaccines.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211216122329/http:/www.bbs.bt/news/?p=163225

The Ministry is still exploring the vaccination of children aged 5-11 with the Pfizer pediatric vaccine. The Pfizer pediatric vaccine is only available to two countries (Israel, USA) as of today.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211209112057/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/19-11-21-%f0%9d%97%a3%f0%9d%97%bf%f0%9d%97%b2%f0%9d%98%80%f0%9d%98%80-%f0%9d%97%bf%f0%9d%97%b2%f0%9d%97%b9%f0%9d%97%b2%f0%9d%97%ae%f0%9d%98%80%f0%9d%97%b2%f0%9d%97%a8%f0%9d%97%bd%f0%9d%97%b1/

As of November 17, the health ministry has vaccinated 76.8 per cent of its overall population including 93.2 per cent of its adult population and 92.8 per cent of the children aged 12-17 years.      https://web.archive.org/web/20211216122329/http:/www.bbs.bt/news/?p=163225
COVID 19 vaccines are fully funded by the government. No change in policy.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301155227/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/28-02-21-information-on-covid-19-vaccine-moh/

These countries are European nations, including UK, as well as South Africa, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Brazil, China, Mauritius, New Zealand, Singapore, Hong Kong and Israel."  "Passengers arriving from South Africa, Botswana and Zimbabwe or passengers who have visited any of these three countries in the last 15 days before arrival in Maharashtra, must undergo mandatory institutional quarantine for seven days after giving their RT-PCR test at the airport.    They shall also undergo a second RT-PCR test on the seventh day. If any test is found to be Covid positive, then such passengers will be moved to a hospital with Covid treatment facilities by the civic body or state authorities. All persons within Nepal are subject to current health protocols, including restrictions on large gatherings. Violations of local orders may result in penalties. Additional restrictions remain possible in many locations. Please see below the US embassy link    https://web.archive.org/web/20211115064301/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Schools across the country resumed in-person classes that were disrupted since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020. Lockdown lifted but all kinds of public gatherings, such as political rallies and mass meetings, jatras and religious festivals with large gatherings of people, remain banned in Kathmandu Valley until further notification.  Kathmandu has allowed movie halls, nightclubs, dohori restaurants to reopen at 50 per cent capacity.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210903111134/https://thehimalayantimes.com/opinion/editorial-no-more-lockdown

There are no restrictions on movements within Nepal. Local and private transportation are available. Public transport and personal vehicles, including taxis, are permitted in the Kathmandu valley and must adhere to strict COVID protocols.  Violations of local orders may result in penalties. Long distance buses may be operating in some areas of the country. Additional restrictions remain possible in many locations.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211115064301/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Commercial flights are operating but with limited availability. The Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal (CAAN) has announced that all domestic flights have resumed, and strict COVID protocols are enforced. Operation of cargo flights, rescue flights, and evacuation flights will be carried out subject to special permission.  Please US embassy link last updated 04/10/21  https://web.archive.org/web/20211115064301/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/     Effective September 24, all fully vaccinated foreigners arriving in Nepal via the immigration office at the airport or a land border can receive on-arrival visas. No quarantine required. Fully-vaccinated travellers travelling to Nepal must present the following documents:  1.Evidence of completion of a 14 day post-COVID-19 vaccination incubation period  2.COVID-19 negative PCR test report obtained within 72 hours of entry into Nepal    On-arrival visas at land border entries are not available to unvaccinated travelers. All unvaccinated and semi-vaccinated travelers must comply with the Government of Nepalâs 10-day quarantine mandate, which requires quarantine at a local hotel at their own cost. A PCR test must be completed and returned negative on 11th day before travelling within the country will be permitted. Such travelers must present the following documents:  1.COVID-19 negative PCR test report obtained within 72 hours of entering the country

According to covid-19 vaccine tracker Nepal has approved 5 vaccine (Astrazeneca, Stupnik V, Covaxin, Sinovac, Sinopharm). See link below:  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018181222/https://covid19.trackvaccines.org/country/nepal/    According to MoH Nepal, as of late November 2021, 31% of the population (including children) have received the 1st dose and 27% are fully vaccinated. Essential businesses can open for 24 hours daily nationwide.    https://archive.vn/UXlVJ#selection-1529.0-1529.59

Localities with vaccination rates of 40-60 percent and below 40 percent can allow gatherings of up to 500 and 300 people, respectively. There are stricter measures ongoing in regions with vaccination rates of below 60 percent.
Localities with vaccination rates of 40-60 percent and below 40 percent can allow gatherings of up to 500 and 300 people, respectively.    https://archive.vn/UXlVJ#selection-1525.609-1525.745
Public transport vehicles can operate with up to 80 percent capacity.    https://archive.vn/UXlVJ#selection-1525.460-1525.528

There are stricter restrictions in areas with vaccination rates of below 60 percent in comparison to areas where vaccination rates are higher.    https://archive.vn/UXlVJ#selection-1525.376-1525.458    https://archive.vn/UXlVJ

No restrictions on internal movement however, there are stricter restrictions in place in areas with vaccination rates of below 60 percent in comparison to areas where vaccination rates are higher.    https://archive.vn/UXlVJ

Travellers arriving by air must submit a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken within 72 hours before arrival and a health declaration form online or via the Pass Track mobile application within 48 hours before arrival. Passengers must undergo on-arrival rapid antigen testing. Symptomatic passengers and those who test positive must quarantine at designated sites until an additional test returns a negative result. Most travel remains banned from Category C areas, which also include Costa Rica, Ethiopia, Guatemala, Iran, Iraq, Mexico, Mongolia, the Philippines, Slovenia, Thailand, and Trinidad and Tobago; exceptions are possible for returning Pakistani citizens who have recently been to these locations.    https://archive.vn/UXlVJ
No income support found.
No change in policy.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210917114828/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#P

Public service messages and COVID-specific guidelines are available on the National Command and Operation Center website    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213132809/https://ncoc.gov.pk/covid-vaccination-en.php  https://archive.vn/p9ViW
PCR tests are widely available.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210422000540/http://www.nhsrc.gov.pk/SiteImage/Misc/files/National%20Testing%20Guidelines.pdf

Across Pakistan, it is mandatory to wear a face mask in public and not wearing one is punishable by a fine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211206143418/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/pakistan/coronavirus
